prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG1: CO(17-16) in J2310
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(17-16) line in J2310. The achievement of SG1 + SG2 + SG3 + SG4 + SG5 would strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with the presence of highly excited CO lines (see OB1 in Sec. 1.3). Given the detection of the continuum at 183 sigma, strong constraints will be obtained on the FIR to CO luminosity ratio in this source. This will allow to define the contribution of shock heating to the CO(17-16) line luminosity (see OB2 in Sec. 1.3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlation setup: Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we would expect the CO(17-16) line to be at a frequency nu_line=279.3 GHz, which is the representative frequency of this Science Goal. This is why we put a SPW centered on nu_line. In the same sideband, we put the other SPW, shifted with respect to nu_line of ~1.3 GHz for the continuum determination. We added 2 SPW in the other sideband for continuum measurements. We will use the continuum measurements to constrain the FIR emission of the galaxy.
Angular Resolution: We request an angular resolution of 1''. From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.5''. The size of the source is therefore expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.
Sensitivity: To quantify the expected CO(17-16) line luminosity in J2310, we combine ALMA Cycle 0 data of its [CII] line, PdBI data of its CO(6-5) line, and PdBI data of the CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1148. Assuming that the line width of the CO(17-16) line in J2310 is of 456 km/s, namely the line width of the CO(6-5) line, we obtain a flux density peak of 2.35 mJy. To resolve the line we need channels of 91.2 km/s. The required sensitivity of 0.47 mJy on channels of 91.2 km/s allows to get a SNR=5 of in the central channel.
Spectral resolution: We use a setup with a bandwidth of 2 GHz (resolution ~ 32 km/s). As mentioned above, to resolve the line we need a 91.2 km/s channels resolution. Therefore the requested resolution is enough for the pourposes of this Science Goal.
Observing time: to reach the required sensitivity a total observing time of 43.42 min is required, with 13.09 min to be spent on the source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG2: CO(14-13) in J1319
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(14-13) line in J1319. The achievement of SG1 + SG2 + SG3 + SG4 + SG5 would strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with the presence of highly excited CO lines (see OB1 in Sec. 1.3). Given the detection of the continuum at 130 sigma, strong constraints will be obtained on the FIR to CO luminosity ratio in this source. This will allow to define the contribution of shock heating to the CO(14-13) line luminosity (see OB2 in Sec. 1.3). The achievement of SG2 + SG3 +SG4 will allow to obtain an accurate measurement of the COSLED in this source. In this way we will test the prediction of our model and will provide strong contraints on the molecular gas properties at z~6 (see OB3 in Sec. 1.3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlation setup: Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we would expect the CO(14-13) line to be at a frequency nu_line=226 GHz, which is the representative frequency of this Science Goal. This is why we put a SPW centered on nu_line. In the same sideband, we put the other SPW, shifted with respect to nu_line of ~1.8 GHz for the continuum determination. We added 2 SPW in the other sideband for continuum measurements. We will use the continuum measurements to constrain the FIR emission of the galaxy.
Angular Resolution: We request an angular resolution of 1''. From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.4''. The size of the source is therefore expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.
Sensitivity: To quantify the expected CO(14-13) line luminosity in J1319, we combine ALMA Cycle 0 data of its [CII] line, PdBI data of its CO(6-5) line, and PdBI data of the CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1148. Assuming that the line width of the CO(14-13) line in J1319 is of 537 km/s, namely the line width of the CO(6-5) line, we obtain a flux density peak of 1.65 mJy. To resolve the line we need channels of 107.4 km/s. The required sensitivity of 0.33 mJy on channels of 107.4 km/s allows to get a SNR=5 of in the central channel.
Spectral resolution: We use a setup with a bandwidth of 2 GHz (resolution ~ 40 km/s). As mentioned above, to resolve the line we need a 107.4 km/s channels resolution. Therefore the requested resolution is enough for the pourposes of this Science Goal. ￼ Observing time: to reach the required sensitivity a total observing time of 46.4 min is required, with 15.34 min to be spent on the source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG3: CO(17-16) in J1319
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(17-16) line in J1319. The achievement of SG1 + SG2 + SG3 + SG4 + SG5 would strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with the presence of highly excited CO lines (see OB1 in Sec. 1.3). Given the detection of the continuum at 148 sigma, strong constraints will be obtained on the FIR to CO luminosity ratio in this source. This will allow to define the contribution of shock heating to the CO(17-16) line luminosity (see OB2 in Sec. 1.3). The achievement of SG2 + SG3 +SG4 will allow to obtain an accurate measurement of the COSLED in this source. In this way we will test the prediction of our model and will provide strong contraints on the molecular gas properties at z~6 (see OB3 in Sec. 1.3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlation setup: Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we would expect the CO(17-16) line to be at a frequency nu_line=273.9 GHz, which is the representative frequency of this Science Goal. This is why we put a SPW centered on nu_line. In the same sideband, we put the other SPW, shifted with respect to nu_line of ~1.9 GHz for the continuum determination. We added 2 SPW in the other sideband for continuum measurements. We will use the continuum measurements to constrain the FIR emission of the galaxy.
Angular Resolution: We request an angular resolution of 1''. From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.4''. The size of the source is therefore expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.
Sensitivity: To quantify the expected CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1319, we combine ALMA Cycle 0 data of its [CII] line, PdBI data of its CO(6-5) line, and PdBI data of the CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1148. Assuming that the line width of the CO(17-16) line in J1319 is of 537 km/s, namely the line width of the CO(6-5) line, we obtain a flux density peak of 1.55 mJy. To resolve the line we need channels of 107.4 km/s. The required sensitivity of 0.31 mJy on channels of 107.4 km/s allows to get a SNR=5 of in the central channel.
Spectral resolution: We use a setup with a bandwidth of 2 GHz (resolution ~ 35 km/s). As mentioned above, to resolve the line we need a 107.4 km/s channels resolution. Therefore the requested resolution is enough for the pourposes of this Science Goal. ￼ Observing time: to reach the required sensitivity a total observing time of 46.45 min is required, with 15.39 min to be spent on the source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG4: CO(19-18) in J1319
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(19-18) line in J1319. The achievement of SG1 + SG2 + SG3 + SG4 + SG5 would strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with the presence of highly excited CO lines (see OB1 in Sec. 1.3). Given the detection of the continuum at 172 sigma, strong constraints will be obtained on the FIR to CO luminosity ratio in this source. This will allow to define the contribution of shock heating to the CO(19-18) line luminosity (see OB2 in Sec. 1.3). The achievement of SG2 + SG3 +SG4 will allow to obtain an accurate measurement of the COSLED in this source. In this way we will test the prediction of our model and will provide strong contraints on the molecular gas properties at z~6. In particular, the detection of the CO(19-18) would exceed our record for the most excited CO transition ever measured at z~6, and will define the CO transition at which the COSLED goes down after the expected peak at J=17 (see OB3 in Sec. 1.3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlation setup: Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we would expect the CO(19-18) line to be at a frequency nu_line=306.3 GHz, which is the representative frequency of this Science Goal. This is why we put a SPW centered on nu_line. In the same sideband, we put the other SPW, shifted with respect to nu_line of ~1.7 GHz for the continuum determination. We added 2 SPW in the other sideband for continuum measurements. We will use the continuum measurements to constrain the FIR emission of the galaxy.
Angular Resolution: We request an angular resolution of 1''. From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.4''. The size of the source is therefore expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.
Sensitivity: To quantify the expected CO(19-18) line luminosity in J1319, we combine ALMA Cycle 0 data of its [CII] line, PdBI data of its CO(6-5) line, and PdBI data of the CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1148. Assuming that the line width of the CO(19-18) line in J1319 is of 537 km/s, namely the line width of the CO(6-5) line, we obtain a flux density peak of 1.45 mJy. To resolve the line we need channels of 107.4 km/s. The required sensitivity of 0.29 mJy on channels of 107.4 km/s allows to get a SNR=5 of in the central channel.
Spectral resolution: We use a setup with a bandwidth of 2 GHz (resolution ~ 31 km/s). As mentioned above, to resolve the line we need a 107.4 km/s channels resolution. Therefore the requested resolution is enough for the pourposes of this Science Goal.
Observing time: to reach the required sensitivity a total observing time of 1.2 hr is required, with 30.17 min to be spent on the source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG5: CO(17-16) in J2054
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(17-16) line in J2054. The achievement of SG1 + SG2 + SG3 + SG4 + SG5 would strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with the presence of highly excited CO lines (see OB1 in Sec. 1.3). Given the detection of the continuum at 75 sigma, strong constraints will be obtained on the FIR to CO luminosity ratio in this source. This will allow to define the contribution of shock heating to the CO(17-16) line luminosity (see OB2 in Sec. 1.3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlation setup: Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we would expect the CO(17-16) line to be at a frequency nu_line=277.9 GHz, which is the representative frequency of this Science Goal. This is why we put a SPW centered on nu_line. In the same sideband, we put the other SPW, shifted with respect to nu_line of ~1.9 GHz for the continuum determination. We added 2 SPW in the other sideband for continuum measurements. We will use the continuum measurements to constrain the FIR emission of the galaxy.
Angular Resolution: We request an angular resolution of 1''. From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.3''. The size of the source is therefore expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.
Sensitivity: To quantify the expected CO(17-16) line luminosity in J2054, we combine ALMA Cycle 0 data of its [CII] line, PdBI data of its CO(6-5) line, and PdBI data of the CO(17-16) line luminosity in J1148. Assuming that the line width of the CO(17-16) line in J2054 is of 360 km/s, namely the line width of the CO(6-5) line, we obtain a flux density peak of 2.25 mJy. To resolve the line we need channels of 72 km/s. The required sensitivity of 0.45 mJy on channels of 72 km/s allows to get a SNR=5 of in the central channel.
Spectral resolution: We use a setup with a bandwidth of 2 GHz (resolution ~ 33 km/s). As mentioned above, to resolve the line we need a 72 km/s channels resolution. Therefore the requested resolution is enough for the pourposes of this Science Goal. ￼ Observing time: to reach the required sensitivity a total observing time of 52.31 min is required, with 18.12 min to be spent on the source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have detected the CO(17-16) emission line in a quasar at z=6.4 through the PdBI. This is the most excited CO transition ever measured in such distant galaxies. The detection of such high-J CO (HJCO) line allows to put strong constraints on the properties of the molecular gas at high-z. Moreover, this discovery suggests that HJCO lines may provide a sensitive, unique tool to infer the presence of X-ray faint or obscured super massive black hole (SMBH) progenitors in galaxies at z>6, thus shedding light on a key problem in cosmic structure formation. To test this exciting hypothesis it is necessary to verify that HJCO lines are specific signatures of high-z quasars. We therefore propose to observe five HJCO lines in three z>6 quasars for which ALMA Cycle 0 observations are already available. The success of our experiment will strongly support the idea that AGN activity is always associated with HJCO lines. The new capabilities offered by ALMA in Cycle 2 allow to open a new pathway for the discovery of SMBH progenitors in only 4.3 hours of total observing time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
